childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1960-1972

Children born in 1960 arrived in the first year of the new decade, alongside John F. Kennedy's election and the promise that a generational transfer of power was underway. Their birth year coincided with the approval of the birth control pill, the Greensboro sit-ins, and the beginning of the end for the postwar domestic consensus their parents had constructed. These children were born, in other words, at the exact moment the 1950s stopped being the 1950s — though the houses, the routines, and the family structures would take years to catch up.

Their early childhood still carried the rhythms of the old order. Mothers at home. Fathers at work. Church on Sunday. Dinner at six. But the television, which had been a source of shared family entertainment, was increasingly delivering content that challenged the premises of the world those routines were designed to maintain. Civil rights marches. Vietnam footage. Presidential press conferences about missiles in Cuba. These children grew up in living rooms where the comfortable and the catastrophic arrived through the same screen, separated by a channel change.

At three, the president was assassinated. These children were toddlers — too young to remember the event itself but old enough to sense its emotional wake. The adults around them were shattered in ways they'd never been before, and children absorbed that disruption even if they couldn't understand its cause. The assassination became part of the atmosphere of their early childhood, referenced and revisited so frequently in the years that followed that it shaped their understanding of the world even without a firsthand memory to anchor it.

At eight, both King and Kennedy were killed, and the country burned. At nine, the moon landing offered a brief reprieve — a moment when the national project seemed to be about aspiration rather than conflict. These children watched Armstrong's first step with the particular intensity of nine-year-olds who understood, without being told, that they were seeing something that mattered enormously. The moon landing was the brightest point in a childhood otherwise marked by escalating domestic turmoil.

The later years of their childhood coincided with the early 1970s — a period of cultural hangover, political scandal, and economic uncertainty. Vietnam was winding down without resolution. Watergate was revealing the presidency as something less noble than the civics textbooks had promised. Their parents' generation, the Silent Generation and early Boomers, was visibly struggling to make sense of a country that had changed faster than anyone expected. These children grew up watching adults improvise, and the improvisation was not always convincing.

What this cohort carries from childhood is a particular kind of flexibility born from living through rapid change. They began in a world that still operated on 1950s assumptions and ended in one that had abandoned most of them. They learned, before they were teenagers, that the rules could change, that the adults didn't always have answers, and that the confident, optimistic America of their earliest years was a historical moment, not a permanent condition. This understanding — pragmatic, unsentimental, earned through observation rather than instruction — would shape how they approached everything that followed.

generational_identity.html:
Baby Boomers

Baby Boomers, born between 1946 and 1964. The name comes from the post-WWII birth spike that produced roughly 76 million Americans. Those born in 1960 numbered 4.3 million—part of a demographic tidal wave that reshaped everything from school construction to diaper manufacturing. The hospitals couldn't keep up. The schools would build additions for decades trying to accommodate them. This cohort was always part of a crowd—the largest generation in history until Millennials eventually caught up.

At three, President Kennedy was shot in Dallas. November 22, 1963. This cohort was toddlers. They might not remember the specific moment, but they remember the weight of it—adults weeping, the television on for days, a feeling that the world had cracked. This is this generation's defining rupture, the moment that split the American century in two. The optimism of Camelot died in that motorcade.

This cohort came of age after the protest generation—or knew someone who was. By the time they hit their teenage years, the 1960s had already happened. They missed Woodstock by three years. They were too young for the Summer of Love but old enough to feel its aftershocks. The counterculture was their older siblings' rebellion; they inherited its music, its skepticism, its complicated relationship with authority.

Vietnam was the wound that wouldn't heal. This cohort was fourteen when Saigon fell, watching helicopters evacuate the last Americans from embassy rooftops. Their older brothers, their friends' brothers, went to war or went to Canada. The draft lottery hung over their childhood like a verdict waiting to be read. They grew up knowing their government could send them to die, and watching it lie about why.

Watergate taught this generation that presidents were criminals. This cohort was thirteen when Nixon resigned, old enough to follow the hearings, to understand that 'I am not a crook' was exactly what a crook would say. Their parents' generation trusted institutions. This generation learned that institutions lie, cheat, and destroy tapes.

This generation is blamed now for the world younger generations inherited—the housing crisis, climate change, stripped pensions, soaring inequality. Some of that blame is fair. Some isn't. They didn't individually decide to offshore manufacturing or gut union protections. They just lived through it, making the best choices they could with the information they had. The 401(k) was sold as freedom, not theft. Suburban sprawl looked like the American Dream, not environmental catastrophe. Hindsight is brutal to everyone who lived through history in real time.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, this cohort was {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. Another rupture, another before-and-after, another moment when the world cracked open and revealed something darker underneath.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

Psycho premiered the year this cohort was born—Janet Leigh's shower scene changing what movies could do to audiences. This cohort wouldn't see it for years, but its influence seeped into every horror film that followed. Alfred Hitchcock taught Hollywood that terror lived in the everyday, that the real monster could be the boy next door.

The music of their birth year still belonged to the 1950s: Chubby Checker teaching America 'The Twist,' Elvis in uniform, doo-wop harmonies on AM radio. But Motown had just been founded in Detroit, and Berry Gordy was assembling the talent that would define their teenage years—Marvin Gaye, Stevie Wonder, The Supremes, The Temptations. The sound of their generation was being born in a two-story house on West Grand Boulevard.

At four, The Beatles landed at JFK Airport, and nothing was ever the same. This cohort watched them on Ed Sullivan with 73 million other Americans, their parents shaking their heads at the hair, the screaming, the chaos. By seven, they'd released Sgt. Pepper, and rock music had become art. This cohort grew up as rock evolved—from 'I Want to Hold Their Hand' to 'Revolution,' from teenage crush to cultural manifesto.

Their Saturday mornings were The Flintstones and The Jetsons. Their after-school hours belonged to reruns of I Love Lucy, The Andy Griffith Show, and Gilligan's Island. At twelve, All in the Family arrived and blew up the wholesome sitcom formula—suddenly television could say 'prejudice' and 'impotence' and 'abortion.' Archie Bunker was their father's generation, mocked and humanized in equal measure.

Their teenage years were Led Zeppelin, Pink Floyd, and The Who. This cohort probably owned Dark Side of the Moon, played it on a turntable with headphones, studying the prism on the cover while the music washed over this cohort. This cohort saw Jaws at fifteen, The Godfather at twelve, Star Wars at seventeen. The 1970s were Hollywood's golden age for actual filmmaking—Taxi Driver, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, Chinatown, Apocalypse Now—and this cohort saw them on screens the size of buildings, not phones the size of their palm.

This cohort taped songs off the radio onto cassettes, timing the pause button to cut out the DJ's voice. This cohort spent hours in record stores—Tower, Sam Goody, Peaches—flipping through albums, judging by cover art because that's all this cohort had. This cohort knew which radio station played what, when. This cohort called in requests and hoped. Music was something this cohort worked for, not something that appeared.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

The television in their childhood living room was furniture—a wooden cabinet with a glass screen that took thirty seconds to warm up. This cohort had three channels, maybe four if the weather cooperated and someone held the antenna at the right angle. When the picture rolled, this cohort adjusted the vertical hold. When it snowed, this cohort knew it wasn't the broadcast—it was their connection to the broadcast.

At five, this cohort watched news from Vietnam in black and white, then in color as families upgraded their sets. By ten, color TV was standard, and the shift felt seismic—suddenly the world had more dimensions. The moon landing was still broadcast in grainy monochrome, but this cohort watched it anyway, nine years old, understanding that the picture quality mattered less than what this cohort was seeing.

The rotary phone hung on their kitchen wall, its curly cord stretched to maximum length when this cohort needed privacy. Long distance was expensive—this cohort planned calls in advance, watched the clock, said goodbye before it cost too much. Their phone number started with a word before it became all digits. This cohort memorized the numbers of everyone this cohort knew because there was no other way.

Calculators arrived when this cohort was in high school—Texas Instruments LED displays that cost a week's wages. Teachers were furious: students would forget how to do math by hand. (They were right, but it didn't matter.) This cohort learned to type on a manual typewriter, pounding keys hard enough to make impressions through carbon paper. The electric typewriter felt like cheating. The word processor, when it came, felt like science fiction.

This cohort was seventeen when the Apple II launched, twenty-one when IBM introduced the PC. Computers were for businesses, for nerds, for people who understood what 'RAM' meant. This cohort might have encountered one at work in the 1980s—green text on black screens, commands this cohort had to memorize, printers that screamed as they worked. By the time computers became normal, this cohort was already an adult with established habits.

The internet arrived when this cohort was thirty-five, email when this cohort was thirty-eight, the World Wide Web when this cohort was forty-three. This cohort adapted because this cohort had to—professionally, then personally. But this cohort never became a native. This cohort know what's been lost: phone calls instead of texts, letters instead of emails, looking things up in books instead of Google, being unreachable when this cohort left the house. This generation is not nostalgic for inconvenience. This generation is nostalgic for presence.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

This cohort was born the year JFK and Nixon faced off in the first televised presidential debate. Nixon looked pale, sweaty, five-o'clock-shadowed. Kennedy looked like a movie star. People who listened on radio thought Nixon won. People who watched on television knew the world had changed. Politics would never again be about what this cohort said—it was about how this cohort looked saying it.

At two, the Cuban Missile Crisis brought the world to the edge of nuclear annihilation. This cohort don't remember it, but this cohort inherited its lessons. The fallout shelter signs in basements. The duck-and-cover drills in elementary school, crouching under desks as if plywood could stop an atom bomb. The awareness, always there, that everything could end in thirty minutes if someone in Moscow or Washington made a mistake.

At three, Dallas. The rupture that defines their generation happened while this cohort was a toddler—the details live in their Generational Identity. Here, what matters is that it launched a decade of violence against leaders that would shape their entire understanding of American power. Innocence ended before this cohort knew what innocence was.

At four, the Civil Rights Act. At five, Selma, Bloody Sunday, the Voting Rights Act. At eight, Martin Luther King Jr. murdered in Memphis, then Bobby Kennedy two months later. The 1960s were a decade of assassinations, and this cohort absorbed them before this cohort could articulate what they meant. Violence against leaders was part of their landscape.

At nine, Apollo 11. Men walked on the moon, and this cohort watched it happen, the whole family gathered around that glowing box, witnesses to the impossible. 'That's one small step for man.' The static. The blur. The absolute certainty that this cohort was seeing something no human had ever seen. For one night, the future looked like it might keep its promises.

At fourteen, Saigon fell. Helicopters evacuating Americans from rooftops, people clinging to landing skids, a war that had defined their adolescence ending not in victory but in chaos. 58,220 Americans died in Vietnam. At fifteen, this cohort watched Nixon resign—'I am not a crook' replaced by 'I shall resign the presidency effective at noon tomorrow.' At {{AGE_AT_911}}, 9/11. At forty-eight, the financial collapse. At sixty, COVID. The crises keep coming. This cohort've survived all of them so far.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

The job market of 1982 offered a challenging entry point. Double-digit inflation. Unemployment over ten percent. Interest rates at eighteen percent for mortgages. Reagan promised morning in America, but the economy was still recovering from recession.

The employment contract that existed when this cohort started looked like this: loyalty for security. Show up early, stay late, prove oneself through decades of service. The company provided health insurance, a pension, the promise of a gold watch and a comfortable retirement. This contract actually existed. It was real.

Then the contract changed. Somewhere in the 1980s and 1990s, companies discovered they could break the old agreement. Pensions became 401(k)s—retirement became the employee's responsibility. Layoffs became 'restructuring,' mass firings became 'right-sizing,' and the job security their parents enjoyed evaporated.

This generation learned technology on the job, whether they wanted to or not. The computer that appeared on desks in 1985. The email system in 1995. The smartphone that fused work and home into one endless obligation. Every five years, the tools changed and they had to relearn everything. Younger colleagues assumed this was easy. It was never easy.

They wore suits. Real suits, with ties that matched and shoes that shined. Business casual was a revolution when it arrived—the memo, the confusion, the men who showed up in golf shirts and got sent home. Dress codes mattered because appearance mattered because the job was a performance, every day, for decades.

Now younger workers want flexible hours, remote options, unlimited vacation, mental health days. They think the way this generation worked—the long hours, the face time, the proving oneself through presence—was unhealthy. They're right. But that was the game, and this generation played it the only way they could.

At {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}, the 2008 financial crisis hit—and retirement plans evaporated overnight. The market recovered eventually. The lesson didn't fade.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Courtship in their era involved actual effort. Learning her class schedule so this cohort could 'accidentally' walk the same route. Working up the nerve to call her house, knowing her father might answer. The sweaty-palmed agony of asking someone to a dance in person, with their voice, while she stood right there and could see their face if she said no.

Dating happened face to face. This cohort went to movies where this cohort sat in the dark together, hyperaware of the armrest between this cohort. This cohort went to diners and ordered things this cohort could afford. This cohort drove around because driving around was its own activity, the radio providing soundtrack to conversations that lasted until someone had to be home by curfew.

This cohort got married younger than their kids will. The median marriage age when this cohort turned twenty-five was around 23 for women, 25 for men. By thirty, most of their friends were married, many with kids. The life script was clear: graduate, get job, get married, buy house, have children. The script worked, mostly, for their generation. It stopped working for the ones who followed.

Divorce was more stigmatized, then less, then more complicated as asset division became a legal industry. Their generation lived through the divorce explosion of the 1970s—this cohort might be a product of it, or a participant, or both. The 'broken home' became just another kind of home. Blended families became normal because they had to.

This cohort communicate differently than younger generations. This cohort pick up the phone and call—actual calls, with their voice, where this cohort can hear the other person breathe. This cohort write emails with proper salutations and sign-offs. This generation is confused by texting's lack of punctuation, by emojis replacing words, by the way their grandchildren can have entire conversations without ever speaking aloud.

Long-distance relationships were hard when long distance cost money. This cohort wrote letters—actual letters, in envelopes, with stamps. This cohort planned phone calls in advance because the minutes added up. This cohort couldn't know where someone was at every moment, and this cohort didn't expect to. Trust meant trusting, not tracking.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Their parents remembered the Great Depression with the clarity of trauma. They saved obsessively. They distrusted debt. They fixed things instead of replacing them, kept pantries stocked, prepared for the worst because they'd lived through the worst. This cohort inherited their caution, even as postwar prosperity suggested caution was unnecessary.

A median house in 1985, when this cohort was twenty-five, cost about $75,000—roughly 2.5 times the median household income. This cohort bought at the right time. The same house now costs over $400,000—more than five times the median income. The math of housing shifted beneath this cohort, lifting this cohort higher without effort.

This cohort watched interest rates do things that would seem fictional now. Mortgage rates hit 18% in 1981. A savings account paid 15%. The rules of money were different—borrowing was expensive, saving was rewarded, inflation was the enemy this cohort actually fought. This cohort learned financial discipline in an economy that demanded it.

The 2008 crisis caught this cohort at the worst moment. This cohort was forty-eight, in their peak earning years, retirement finally visible on the horizon—and their 401(k) lost half its value. Their house was suddenly underwater. Everything this cohort'd built through decades of discipline and delayed gratification turned precarious overnight. The market recovered, eventually. The lesson didn't fade: the floor can fall out at any moment.

Social Security sits in their mind like a promise that might be broken. This cohort've paid in for forty-plus years. The projections say it will be there, mostly, with adjustments. But this cohort've seen enough promises broken to hedge their bets. This generation is planning as if it might not exist, hoping that it will, understanding that hope is not a financial strategy.

The 401(k) replaced the pension during their career—all the risk transferred to this cohort, all the responsibility for investing correctly, all the anxiety about whether their spreadsheets were right. Their parents got defined benefits and never worried about outliving their money. This cohort got flexibility, control, and chronic uncertainty.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

This cohort worked hard for what this cohort have. This is true. The danger is assuming that hard work is the only variable—that anyone who worked as hard as this cohort would have achieved what this cohort achieved. The economy that rewarded their labor doesn't exist anymore. Entry-level jobs that bought houses in their twenties require graduate degrees and pay less now. 'Just work harder' is advice from a world that stopped existing.

Their relationship with technology is functional but shallow. This cohort use it, but this cohort don't understand it—not really. This makes this cohort vulnerable in ways this cohort don't always see: to scams, to misinformation, to algorithms designed to exploit exactly the kind of trust this cohort extend. Healthy skepticism about the internet isn't the same as understanding how it works.

The progress this cohort witnessed can blind this cohort to the regression others experience. This cohort watched civil rights legislation pass, women enter the workforce, gay marriage become legal. It looks like a straight line toward justice. But rights gained can be rights lost, and the backlash is always building. Younger generations feel the precarity of progress in ways this cohort might not viscerally understand.

This cohort trust institutions that have spent decades proving they're untrustworthy. Not all of them, not blindly, but enough. The news anchor, the doctor, the financial advisor, the politician who reminds this cohort of someone this cohort liked once. Younger generations' cynicism isn't just attitude—it's evidence-based. They've watched institutions fail in real time, without the memory of when those institutions functioned.

Climate change is their generation's greatest blind spot. Not because this cohort caused it—the CO2 was accumulating long before their birth—but because this cohort benefited from the cheap energy that accelerated it, and many of this cohort remain reluctant to accept the bill. The suburbs this cohort built, the cars this cohort drove, the flights this cohort took, the consumption that defined postwar prosperity—these have costs that their grandchildren will pay.

This cohort survived so much that survival itself became an identity. The assassinations, the wars, the recessions, the crashes. But survival isn't the same as understanding. This cohort can live through something without learning from it, can absorb trauma without processing it, can pass on unexamined pain to generations who didn't sign up for the inheritance.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Their 20s (1980-1990): This cohort entered adulthood during stagflation, oil shocks, and disco's death rattle. Reagan promised morning in America; this cohort was hoping for a job that paid rent. The economy recovered midway through the decade, and so did their prospects. If this cohort got married, this cohort probably did it here—median age was twenty-three, twenty-five. If this cohort bought a house, interest rates were brutal but prices were human. This cohort built the foundation of adult life in a decade that swung from malaise to excess, from gas lines to greed-is-good.

Their 30s (1990-2000): The Soviet Union collapsed. The Cold War ended. The existential threat this cohort'd lived under since birth simply vanished. The 1990s felt like exhaling—the economy boomed, crime dropped, the internet emerged, the future looked digital and prosperous. This cohort was in their prime earning years, climbing whatever ladder this cohort'd chosen. If this cohort had kids, they were young enough to need this cohort. The American Dream, battered but functional, still seemed achievable.

Their 40s (2000-2010): September 11, 2001. This cohort was forty-one, old enough to understand immediately that everything had changed, old enough to remember what it felt like before. The decade brought two wars, one stolen election (maybe two), and a financial crisis that vaporized trillions. Their retirement accounts cratered at forty-eight. Their kids were teenagers, or adults, watching this cohort absorb shocks and pretend to be fine. This cohort learned that midlife crisis isn't a cliché—it's a reasonable response to accumulating evidence.

Their 50s (2010-2020): Recovery, supposedly. The economy limped back. Their 401(k) regained its value, or most of it. Their kids left, or didn't, or left and came back. Their parents aged, needed care, died. This cohort became the oldest generation in their family, the one who remembered things nobody else was alive to remember. Retirement started to feel real—not distant, not someday, but soon. This cohort counted years differently.

Their 60s (2020-present): COVID arrived when this cohort was sixty. Suddenly this cohort was the vulnerable population, the demographic hospitals triage against, the reason for lockdowns. Retirement, if this cohort could afford it, started looking different than this cohort'd imagined. Less golf, more anxiety. Their grandchildren, if this cohort have them, are growing up in a world this cohort barely recognize—their phones, their memes, their certainty that previous generations broke everything. This generation is supposed to be enjoying the fruits of a lifetime's labor. Some days this cohort do. Some days the fruit tastes like ash.

Looking ahead: Life expectancy for their cohort is roughly 78-82 years. This cohort've got time, but not unlimited time. The question is what this cohort do with it—how much this cohort can repair, reconcile, pass on. Legacy becomes unavoidable. The stories this cohort tell, the lessons this cohort share, the things this cohort wish this cohort'd done differently. Their generation is rewriting what aging looks like, refusing the rocking chair, staying engaged past the ages when their grandparents disappeared. The ending isn't written yet. This generation is still holding the pen.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US the same year as this generation—part of a 76 million generation. this generation've been the main character of American history for sixty years. That era is ending.

Compared to the Silent Generation (born 1928-1945): They were too young for World War II but too old for rock and roll. They followed the rules, trusted institutions, built careers in single companies. They got pensions. They retired at sixty-five. They were the last generation to believe fully in the American bargain: work hard, play by the rules, get taken care of. this generation questioned that bargain. Their children discovered it had been revoked.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): The forgotten middle children. They came of age during divorce culture, latchkey childhoods, and the AIDS crisis. They were too young for Vietnam, too old for the internet's native benefits. They're perpetually overshadowed—by their generation's cultural dominance, by Millennials' grievances, by their own studied indifference. They got the same degrees this generation did but entered a job market that was already beginning to fray. They adapted by expecting nothing.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): Their generation controls 52% of American wealth while comprising 21% of the population. They graduated into craters—2008, 2020, whatever comes next. They did everything this generation told them (college, degrees, 'follow their passion') and got student debt and unpaid internships. The resentment runs deep. Some of it is displaced. Not all of it.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): They were born after the internet, after 9/11, after the old world stopped existing. They've never known a stable climate, a functional political consensus, or a housing market they could enter. They communicate in images and irony because words failed long before they arrived. They're not cynical—they're realistic about a system that never promised them anything. They don't hate this generation personally. They just don't believe anything this generation built will last.

The wealth gap tells the story: their generation controlled 21% of national wealth at the age Millennials are now. They control about 7%. These aren't personal failings—they're structural transfers, policy choices, the accumulated advantage of being born when the ladder still had rungs. this generation didn't steal anything. The system this generation participated in simply funneled resources upward, and this generation happened to be up.

Their life expectancy at birth was about 70 years. Modern medicine extended that—this generation can reasonably expect 80, maybe longer with luck and good genes. this generation've outlived more assumptions than any generation before this generation. The world this generation was born into—rotary phones, black-and-white TV, segregated lunch counters—has vanished. The world this generation'll leave behind is unrecognizable. That's the Boomer experience: everything changed, including this generation.

year_events: The Flintstones premiered as first prime-time animated show
Birth control pill approved by FDA
